I say if we start with Marsh and which was no state action a privately owned town in Marsh.
And as I appreciate the case --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Marsh, as I recall it, didn't say that a state couldn't have laws that are against trespass, they have to warn you of leaving the property after notice.

turn.speaker: john_p_nelson
turn.label: Mr. John P. Nelson, Jr.
turn.text: No sir.
But the way I read the Marsh with the privately owned town of Marsh but no state involvement.
This was the day -- this was set up as a characterization of a particular piece of property so as to define the limits of legal rights being exercised on it, apply that to McCrory's.
And then we come up to date on the Shelley versus Kraemer.

And I submit that on the basis of these two cases, as far as I appreciate the jurisprudence, we can come to an answer -- we can come to the -- to the legal conclusion that the preferred right of these kids to demonstrate in a manner in which they did, and the circumstances which were -- within which the act took place and the environment that covered the whole thing that to be accused of trespassing was a depri -- was a violation of their Fourteenth Amendment rights.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: May I ask you just one thing.
I don't -- I want to see just the exact link of the argument you've just made.

turn.speaker: john_p_nelson
turn.label: Mr. John P. Nelson, Jr.
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Are you saying that the State is without power by reason of the Federal Constitution or that owners of property of the store were unable because of the Federal Constitution to decide who they'll sell and who they want to sell and the conditions under which they will serve customers of the store.
Do you have to go that far in this case?

turn.speaker: john_p_nelson
turn.label: Mr. John P. Nelson, Jr.
turn.text: Because of the strong state action in this case --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well that --

turn.speaker: john_p_nelson
turn.label: Mr. John P. Nelson, Jr.
turn.text: -- I think we can go that far.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I understand.
I understand that fully.

But the issue, basic issue, when you get to bottom of some of these cases here whether an owner of a store can do this and whether because he has a right to do it, the State can call its officials to help enforce his legal rights.

turn.speaker: john_p_nelson
turn.label: Mr. John P. Nelson, Jr.
turn.text: In McCrory's, or stores open to public.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, all stores open to the public.

turn.speaker: john_p_nelson
turn.label: Mr. John P. Nelson, Jr.
turn.text: Well not -- not the Morrison's cafeteria in the city.
They stopped at the sidewalk.
I wouldn't say that it was open to the public, not Saenger Theater.
It's a property that's vested -- it has a public faculty about it.
But it's really not open to the public and they might -- they put on white only sign the barbershop that might want just to wait on white man.
The manicurist --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Could they say that?

turn.speaker: john_p_nelson
turn.label: Mr. John P. Nelson, Jr.
turn.text: Sir?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Could the barbershop say that?

turn.speaker: john_p_nelson
turn.label: Mr. John P. Nelson, Jr.
turn.text: Could he say it?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But the Fourteen Amendment forbids the barbershop saying that.

turn.speaker: john_p_nelson
turn.label: Mr. John P. Nelson, Jr.
turn.text: Well Your Honor they --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That it will serve only white or serve only colored.
Why does your argument take it too on the case of that county?

turn.speaker: john_p_nelson
turn.label: Mr. John P. Nelson, Jr.
turn.text: I won't -- well we're not -- I haven't.
Frankly, to answer your question I have not thought that through yet.
Because they have an element of privacy -- of privacy, an element of privacy in there, that we don't have in the McCrory type situation where you --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But I find a bit trouble to myself.
It's maybe because I'm too liberal.
But I find a great trouble myself seeing some store, some merchant dealers down there can choose their customers and some cannot.
It would seem to me that if the man and the country place could by his door is wide open to everybody who wants to come in and you tell them not to.
He would be governed by the Constitution on that just the same as McCrory or if the Constitution forbids him to choose his costumers on account of color.

turn.speaker: john_p_nelson
turn.label: Mr. John P. Nelson, Jr.
turn.text: Sir, if the -- if that is the predominant right, every, every dispense of a goods of the City of New Orleans could refuse to serve every Negro, at what point then --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, are you -- are you saying that the Federal Constitution without any legislation to back it, bars a merchant from following that course, that is, as I understand it, it's ultimately the basic issue that would sometimes have to be reach in some of these cases, maybe not indeed?

turn.speaker: john_p_nelson
turn.label: Mr. John P. Nelson, Jr.
turn.text: Not indeed, sir.

And insofar as the -- as to whether the Constitution would prohibit a manager from actually serving the costumer I would approach it on this that I believe that the Constitution would prohibit a Negro from protesting at that very counter if it's open to the public, that he'd not be serve.
And that for that protest I don't think he should be -- the Constitution keep him out of jail.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: The question behind that would still be whether he can go into a mercantile establishment against the will of the owner or stay there against the will of the owner in order to make his speech of protest.
Are you saying he could?

turn.speaker: john_p_nelson
turn.label: Mr. John P. Nelson, Jr.
turn.text: Absolutely, under circumstances of which these demonstrations took place I say this was free speech and they were invited in and they can do it.
I respectfully submit that they can.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I understand with reference to your argument, that you are in fact saying that no matter what how you answered the question of whether or not a storeowner has the right to discuss it -- that it's unquestionably clear that the State has no right to chose them for it, and that in this case, the State chose them for it.

turn.speaker: john_p_nelson
turn.label: Mr. John P. Nelson, Jr.
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That is one of your -- one branch of your argument.

turn.speaker: john_p_nelson
turn.label: Mr. John P. Nelson, Jr.
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And if you're correct on that whether these other questions are in the case.

turn.speaker: john_p_nelson
turn.label: Mr. John P. Nelson, Jr.
turn.text: That's correct, sir.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Is that true?

turn.speaker: john_p_nelson
turn.label: Mr. John P. Nelson, Jr.
turn.text: That's true.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And it's only if you answer that question in a certain way that you must reach the other branch of your argument you'd stated today in which I didn't understand you stated yesterday, that a store is such an establishment.
That it may not discriminate because a store per se is a state action for the purposes of the Fourteenth Amendment.

turn.speaker: john_p_nelson
turn.label: Mr. John P. Nelson, Jr.
turn.text: That's correct.
But with the requesting of court possibility that this case may be sent back for a new trial.
And I would respectfully request that that'd be done, that these questions in this case of these issues be defined so that we'll have some guidance to prevent the reappearing in 1964.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: May I ask you if we sent back under Louisiana law whether it would now be moot since all of the stores are permitting them to come in?

turn.speaker: john_p_nelson
turn.label: Mr. John P. Nelson, Jr.
turn.text: I don't think that we --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But I --

turn.speaker: john_p_nelson
turn.label: Mr. John P. Nelson, Jr.
turn.text: -- I don't think the governor would dismiss these cases.
The environment is not -- that I don't know.
I -- I'm sure it would be moot, be a question of whether the District Attorney would want it just arbitrarily nolle prosequi the cases.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But if they're -- would be moot then, they're moot now.

turn.speaker: john_p_nelson
turn.label: Mr. John P. Nelson, Jr.
turn.text: Well I don't -- there is -- there is a jail sentence facing these kids --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, there still would be but how would it change if these cases were sent back how in terms of mootness would the situation had been changed?

turn.speaker: john_p_nelson
turn.label: Mr. John P. Nelson, Jr.
turn.text: Well, if they know mootness insofar is concerned.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) I mean that somebody has to take some actions before the State would do that?

turn.speaker: john_p_nelson
turn.label: Mr. John P. Nelson, Jr.
turn.text: That's correct, sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But if there had been a statute in that state which forbad this to be done, and the State had changed it, many states hold under those circumstances the pending actions obeyed cannot presume the same thing would be through of the judgment.
Although not a statute, it's a common law it -- it's a custom.

The law has been forbidden and that law changes, their custom changes, the practice of the State changes, the State could well hope if it wanted to and it might that all actions pending on it had obeyed it, but that was the question.

turn.speaker: john_p_nelson
turn.label: Mr. John P. Nelson, Jr.
turn.text: Your Honor, of course they -- Louisiana and I respectfully submit it would not because it depends -- would not, because the pendency of absolved.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: If we affirm this judgment.
We have to do it on the basis on the assumption that this person goes to jail.

turn.speaker: john_p_nelson
turn.label: Mr. John P. Nelson, Jr.
turn.text: You would.
There's no question --

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: Perhaps the governor would be soft-hearted in pardoning for something.
We couldn't make that assumption.

turn.speaker: john_p_nelson
turn.label: Mr. John P. Nelson, Jr.
turn.text: No sir.
Because of the fact there's -- the pendency of so many cases in Alexandria, in Shreveport and in other areas in Louisiana where this is still a vital issue.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Very well, Mr. Nelson.
